resources.string: High risk. Total score 8—20. Skip the additional step-by-step questionnaire and turn to a specialist immediately for consulting and further decision on whether or not early intervention is necessary.

Moderate risk. Total score 3—7. Complete additional step-by-step questionnaire (second stage MCHAT-R/F) to get more information about answers pointing to ASD risks. Recommended course of action is to turn to a specialist for consulting and further decision on whether or not early intervention is necessary. If the examination reveals no ASD symptoms, no further actions are necessary. The child should be re-examined in the future.
Low risk. Total score 0—2. If the child is under 24 months, test them again after the age of 2. If the test reveals no ASD symptoms, no further actions are necessary.
In order for the test to be as precise as possible, you should complete an additional step-by-step questionnaire (M-CHAT-R/F). You can download the files at link.

string-array.name: test_autism_description_paragraphs
string-array.item: M-CHAT-R has as high detection rate of autism spectrum disorders (ASD) as possible. However, there is also a high risk of false positive.
Counting algorithm: a \"No\" for all questions except 2, 5 and 12, points to the risk of ASD. A \"Yes\" for questions 2, 5 and 12 points to the risk of ASD.

Please, answer the following questions about your child. When answering, rely on how the child behaves usually. If you have occasionally noticed this kind of behaviour but it’s not habitual, answer \"No\". The test is designed to detect children who require thorough diagnostics of development complications, including diagnosing autism symptoms.

string-array.name: test_autism
string-array.item: When you point at something in the opposite end of the room, does the child look at it? E.g. when you point at a toy or an animal, does the child look at it?
Have you ever suspected your child being deaf?
Does your child play imagine or role-play games? E.g. pretend they are drinking out of an empty cup, talking on the phone, feeding a doll or a stuffed toy?
Does your child like climbing on objects? E.g. furniture, structures on the playground, stairs or ladders.
Does your child make weird finger movements in front of their eyes? E.g. moving their fingers near the eyes.
Does your child point their finger at something to ask for it or get help? E.g. pointing at a treat or a toy they can’t reach.
Does your child point their finger at something of interest to draw your attention to it? E.g. pointing a finger at a plane in the sky or a big truck on the road.
Does your child show interest in other children? E.g. watching other children, smiling at them, trying to approach them?
Does your child pick up items and bring them to show you? E.g. showing you a flower, a stuffed toy or a toy truck.
Does your child respond when you call their name? Like look back at you, speak or babble, stop doing whatever they are doing at the moment?
Does your child smile back when you smile at him?
Does household noise upset your child? E.g. they cry or scream when they hear a vacuum cleaner or loud music.
Can your child walk?
Does the child look you in the eyes when you are talking to them, dressing them or playing with them?
Does the child try to copy what you are doing? E.g. waving their hand when saying goodbye, clapping their hands, making funny noises when you are doing it.
If you turn around to look at something, does your child start looking around to see what you are looking at?
Does the child try to make you look at them? E.g. the child looks at you waiting to be praised, or says \"look\" or \"look at me\".
Does the child understand being told to do something? E.g. if you don’t point at anything, does your child understand phrases like \"put the book on the chair\" or \"bring me the blanket\"?
When something unusual happens, does the child look at your face to see how you react to it? E.g. if they hear a strange or funny nose or see a new toy, will they look at your face?
Does your child like activities like being pushed on a swing or rocked on the knees?
